qas.question: What books prompted a textual analysis of modern work?

context: Many ancient works, such as <b8_0>the Bible and the <b5_0>Greek tragedies<b8_0/><b5_0/>,[citation needed] survive in hundreds of copies, and the relationship of each copy to <b7_0>the original may be unclear<b7_0/>. Textual scholars have debated for centuries <b6_0>which sources are most closely derived from the original<b6_0/>, hence which readings in those sources are correct.[citation needed] Although <a1_0>biblical books that are letters, like Greek plays, presumably had one original<a1_0/>, <a2_0>the question of whether some biblical books, like the Gospels, ever had just one original has been discussed<a2_0/>. Interest in applying textual criticism to the <a0_0>Qur'an<a0_0/> has also developed after the discovery of the <a3_0><b9_0>Sana'a manuscripts<b9_0/><a3_0/> in 1972, which <a4_0>possibly date back to the 7–8th centuries.
